### Problem If I understand it correctly, documentation about startup states that each dir in `$XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` is searched for a `nvim/init.lua` file. (Where `nvim/` should be replaced by `NVIM_APPNAME` if applicable, I believe.) From https://neovim.io/doc/user/starting.html#startup, specifically point `7.b`, the 3rd bullet: ``` b. Locations searched for initializations, in order of preference: - $VIMINIT environment variable (Ex command line). - User |config|: $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/nvim/init.vim (or init.lua). - Other config: {dir}/nvim/init.vim (or init.lua) where {dir} is any directory in $XDG_CONFIG_DIRS. - $EXINIT environment variable (Ex command line). |$MYVIMRC| is set to the first valid location unless it was already set or when using $VIMINIT. ``` This does not seem to be the case. ### Steps to reproduce Some example init files: `example-xdg-config-dir/nvim/init.lua`: ``` vim.notify("hello from XDG_CONFIG_DIRS/nvim/init.lua", vim.log.levels.INFO) ``` `example-xdg-config-dir/example-nvim-appname/init.lua`: ``` vim.notify("hello from XDG_CONFIG_DIRS/example-nvim-appname/init.lua", vim.log.levels.INFO) ``` Run nvim: ```sh NVIM_APPNAME=example-nvim-appname XDG_CONFIG_DIRS="$(pwd)/example-xdg-config-dir${XDG_CONFIG_DIRS:+:$XDG_CONFIG_DIRS}" nvim -V3./nvim-startup.$(date +%F-%H%M%S).log ``` ``` :messages -- blank :echo $MYVIMRC -- blank ``` The startup log does not mention the `init.lua` files in `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS`.

comment_data.body:
~~I suppose this is technically correct but not eager to spend time on it until it has actual demand (e.g. upvotes on this issue). Have never heard anyone actually ask for this.~~

Edit: I misunderstood, the issue is: we already support this for `init.vim`, we just never got around to it for `init.lua`. So yes this is needed.

Why do I even want to use `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS`?

(I'm adding this from PR discussion to the issue for clarity.)

I got here through my adventures in using Nix to wrap NeoVim.

"Wrapping" here refers to bundling configuration files, ENV variables, CLI arguments, etc. with a specific version of a program to produce a reproducible pre-configured version of that program. It's basically a shell script that starts the underlying program with extra options.

For NeoVim, adding a path to a directory with a full regular NeoVim configuration (from the Nix store) to `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` seemed like my most safe option.

Overwriting `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` seemed like a bad idea, but adding to `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` (combined with `NVIM_APPNAME`) seemed perfect. It promises to do basically exactly the same as what a regular config in `XDG_CONFIG_HOME` would do.

Except that `init.lua` files aren't actually sourced... And `NVIM_APPNAME` isn't respected.

The lua files in `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` are on the runtimepath. I loaded the `init.lua` by using `-u` for a while, but then ran into issues where `exrc` related stuff is skipped.

I'm currently using a custom `VIMINIT` in favor of `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` to source my config. I think it's emulating what the initialization for `XDG_CONFIG_DIRS` would do.

```lua
vim.env.MYVIMRC = [[${configSource}/init.lua]]
vim.opt.runtimepath:prepend([[${configSource}]])
vim.opt.runtimepath:append([[${configSource}/after]])
vim.cmd.source([[${configSource}/init.lua]])
```
